item.title: Cartesian Product
item.description: Cartesian product The cartesian product is the all ordered pairs of two or more sets.

item.title: Difference between Permutation and Combination
item.description: A [[nibm_notes/mathematics_for_computing/permutations_and_combination/what_is_permutation|permutation ]] has to have an order and a [[nibm_notes/mathematics_for_computing/permutations_and_combination/what_is_combination|combination ]] doesn’t have an order. A combination is a subset of the permutation

item.title: Function
item.description: Function A function is a relation in which there is only one output for each input

item.title: Reflexive
item.description: Reflexive A relation is reflexive if every element is related to itself (a, a) € R

item.title: Reflexive
item.description: Relation A relation is relationship between sets of values, or it is a subset of the Cartesian product

item.title: Reflexive
item.description: Symmetric A relation is symmetric if for every (a, b) € R it needs to be (b, a) € R, it is twin of().

item.title: Transitive
item.description: Transitive A relation is transitive if for every (a, b) € R and (b, c) € R the (a, c) € R

item.title: What is Combination
item.description: What is combination a mathematical technique that determines the number of possible arrangements in a collection of items where the order of the selection does not matter

item.title: What is Permutation
item.description: What is permutation The term permutation refers to a mathematical calculation of the number of ways a particular set can be arranged

item.title: What is the difference between Cartesian Product and Relation
item.description: What is the difference between Cartesian product and relation Every [[nibm_notes/mathematics_for_computing/sets_and_relations/relation|relation ]] is a subset of the [[nibm_notes/mathematics_for_computing/sets_and_relations/cartesian_product|Cartesian product]]

item.title: What is the difference between Relation and Function
item.description: What is the difference between relationship and a function a [[nibm_notes/mathematics_for_computing/sets_and_relations/relation|relationship]] can have many outputs for a single input, but a [[nibm_notes/mathematics_for_computing/sets_and_relations/function_math|function]] has a single input for a single output
